enforcing_agency: Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre-AUSTRAC
summary: The Federal Court of Australia ordered Westpac to pay a A$1.3 billion penalty for an enormous number of breaches of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006. There was also deficiencies in the way it handled transactions that could have been linked to child exploitation.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) can confirm a settlement has been reached with Rio Tinto Ltd. The settlement brings an end to all tax disputes including long standing disputes in relation to Rio's Singapore marketing hub. The settlement brings Rio's total payment in relation to the disputes to almost $1 billion.

enforcing_agency: Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre-AUSTRAC
summary: An agreement was reached between AUSTRAC and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) for a A$700 million penalty to resolve Federal Court proceedings relating to serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing (AML/CTF) laws.
BHP signed an agreement with Australia's tax authorities to settle a long-running dispute over the global miner's operations in Singapore.

enforcing_agency: Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre-AUSTRAC
summary: Crown Melbourne and Crown Perth, casinos owned by Crown Resorts, which in turn is owned by Blackstone, agreed to pay a A$450 million penalty to resolve allegations of having breached the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006.

Singapore Telecommunications, or Singtel, announced it would have to pay S$295 million in additional taxes, interest and penalties after losing an appeal of a decision by the Australian Tax Office concerning the acquisition of Cable and Wireless Optus.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: ANZ admitted to engaging in unconscionable conduct in services it provided to the Australian Government, incorrectly reporting its bond trading data to the Australian Government by overstating the volumes by tens of billions of dollars and to widespread misconduct across products and services impacting nearly 65,000 customers.

Petroleum operator PTTEP agreed to pay A$192 million to settle litigation brought in Australia by Indonesian seaweed farmers affected by the 2009 Montara offshore drilling explosion and oil spill in the Timor Sea.
The Federal Court ordered Singapore Airlines to pay $11.75 million in penalties for engaging in cartel conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010).

The Federal Court has ordered Volkswagen AG to pay $125 million in penalties, after it declared by consent that Volkswagen breached the Australian Consumer Law by making false representations about compliance with Australian diesel emissions standards.
BHP has lost a High Court appeal in a tax case over its controversial Singapore marketing hub, leaving it with a S$125 million tax bill.

Qantas agreed to pay A$20 million in customer compensation and a A$100 million penalty to resolve a lawsuit brought by the ACCC alleging the company sold thousands of tickets for flights that had already been cancelled.

Optus was ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of A$100 million for engaging in unconscionable conduct when selling mobile phones and contracts to hundreds of Australians, and subsequent debt collection in a case brought by the ACCC.

Optus admitted to engaging in unconscionable conduct when selling telecommunications goods and services to hundreds of consumers, after court action brought by the ACCC. Many of the affected consumers were vulnerable or experiencing disadvantage, such as living with a mental disability, diminished cognitive capacity or learning difficulties, being financially dependent or unemployed, having limited financial literacy or English not being a first language. Many of the consumers were First Nations Australians from regional, remote and very remote parts of Australia.

Westpac committed to remediating customers whose financial advisers may have failed to notify them of corporate actions between 2005 and 2019. Westpac estimated approximately A$87m would be paid in compensation to affected customers who were former clients of Westpac's advice businesses and held ASX-listed securities through platforms.
An Australian court fined Qantas a record A$90m for illegally sacking more than 1,800 ground workers during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia agreed to refund approximately A$80 million to around 216,000 Wealth Package customers as compensation for failing to apply fee waivers, interest concessions and other benefits since 2008. The refund payments include an additional amount of interest to recognise the time elapsed since the relevant benefit was not applied. CBA reported this matter to ASIC under its breach reporting obligations in the Corporations Act.

ASIC has accepted an Enforceable Undertaking (EU) from car financier, BMW Australia Finance Limited, to compensate customers for its responsible lending failures. The agreement provided for A$72 million in customer redress and a A$5 million community benefit payment.

The Federal Court has ordered Google LLC to pay $60 million in penalties for making misleading representations to consumers about the collection and use of their personal location data on Android phones between January 2017 and December 2018, following court action by the ACCC.

Westpac Banking Corporation back-paid nearly 47,000 staff to rectify underpayments over a period of 11 years and signed an Enforceable Undertaking with the Fair Work Ombudsman. The underpayments were primarily caused by failures in Westpac's systems, governance processes, and compliance oversight. Further shortcomings included inadequate record-keeping, reliance on systems requiring manual adjustments, and input errors. Employees were underpaid their casual loading and minimum wages for ordinary hours; allowances such as for higher duties and weekend penalties; termination payments, leave payments and more. As of the announcement, Westpac had back-paid a total of more than A$50.26 million, plus almost A$9 million in interest and applicable superannuation, to nearly 47,000 current and former staff who were underpaid between January 2014 and February 2025. Westpac was also required to an A$800,000 contrition payment to the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Federal Court ordered that Telstra pay $50 million in penalties for engaging in unconscionable conduct when it sold mobile contracts to more than 100 Indigenous consumers across three states and territories, in proceedings brought by the ACCC.

After the company dropped its appeal, the Federal Court approved a payment plan for airline PT Garuda Indonesia Ltd to pay a $19 million penalty the Court previously ordered relating to a long-running ACCC action against a global price fixing cartel in the air cargo industry.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank entered into enforceable undertakings with ASIC in relation to each bank's bank bill trading business and its participation in the setting of the Bank Bill Swap Rate (BBSW), a key Australian benchmark and reference interest rate. The Federal Court imposed pecuniary penalties of A$10 million each on ANZ and NAB for the attempts to engage in unconscionable conduct in respect of the setting of BBSW. The Court also noted that each of ANZ and NAB will give Enforceable Undertakings to ASIC which required them to take certain steps and to pay A$20 million to be applied to the benefit of the community, and that each will pay A$20 million towards ASIC's investigation and other costs.

Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank entered into enforceable undertakings with ASIC in relation to each bank's bank bill trading business and its participation in the setting of the Bank Bill Swap Rate (BBSW), a key Australian benchmark and reference interest rate. The Federal Court imposed pecuniary penalties of A$10 million each on ANZ and NAB for the attempts to engage in unconscionable conduct in respect of the setting of BBSW. The Court also noted that each of ANZ and NAB will give Enforceable Undertakings to ASIC which required them to take certain steps and to pay A$20 million to be applied to the benefit of the community, and that each will pay A$20 million towards ASIC's investigation and other costs.
Steel manufacturer BlueScope Steel was ordered to pay a A$57.5 million penalty for attempting to fix prices for flat steel products supplied in Australia.
Allianz Australia Insurance Limited agreed to refund A$45.6 million to 68,000 customers for add-on insurance sold through car dealerships that were of little to no value.

Google admitted that it engaged in anti-competitive practices via agreements with Telstra and Optus regarding the pre-installation of Google Search on Android mobile phones. Google agreed to pay a total penalty of A$55 million.

The Full Federal Court ordered Japanese company Yazaki Corporation to pay increased penalties of $46 million for cartel conduct, following an appeal by the ACCC. The trial judge had earlier found that Yazaki had engaged in anti-competitive cartel conduct in the supply of wire harnesses used in the manufacture of the Toyota Camry. The Full Court dismissed Yazaki's cross-appeal of the trial judge's finding that it had engaged in cartel conduct.

The Federal Court ordered Trivago to pay penalties of $44.7 million for making misleading representations about hotel room rates on its website and in television advertising, in proceedings brought by the ACCC.

enforcing_agency: Office of the Australian Information Commissioner
summary: The Australian Information Commissioner agreed to a A$50 million payment program as part of an enforceable undertaking (EU) received from Meta Platforms, Inc. to settle civil penalty proceedings. The payment scheme was open to eligible Australian Facebook users impacted by the Cambridge Analytica matter. The Commissioner alleged that the personal information of some Australian Facebook users was disclosed to the This is Your Digital Life app in breach of the Privacy Act 1988 (Cth). The information was exposed to the risk of disclosure to Cambridge Analytica and other third parties, and risked being used for political profiling purposes.
The Federal Court penalized Westpac A$40 million for charging advice fees to over 11,800 deceased customers.

Westpac admitted breaching its responsible lending obligations when providing home loans and agreed to submit to a A$35 million civil penalty to resolve Federal Court proceedings under the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009 (Cth) (the National Credit Act). A three-week trial for this matter was due to commence in the Federal Court yesterday.

Insurance Australia Group Limited (IAG) entities have back-paid workers more than A$21 million owed under federal workplace laws and signed an Enforceable Undertaking (EU) with the Fair Work Ombudsman. The underpayments were caused by basic shortcomings in the IAG entities' processes, including not having time and attendance systems in place, resulting in them not paying employees for their actual hours of work. In addition, the IAG entities back-paid workers a total of A$16.2 million in long service leave entitlements that was owed under state and territory laws between 2013 and 2022. IAG also made a A$650,000 contrition payment to the Commonwealth's Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Japanese shipping company Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd (K-Line) was convicted of criminal cartel conduct and ordered by the Federal Court to pay a fine of $34.5 million. The Federal Court found K-Line engaged in a cartel with other shipping companies in order to fix prices on the transportation of cars, trucks, and buses to Australia between 2009 and 2012.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited agreed to refund A$28.8 million to 376,570 retail accounts, and 17,230 business accounts, after it failed to clearly disclose when certain periodical payment fees would apply.

The Federal Court ordered Airbnb Ireland UC (Airbnb) to pay A$15 million in penalties and Airbnb agreed to offer up to A$15 million in compensation to eligible consumers, after Airbnb admitted it misled consumers about the currency of the prices on its accommodation platform.
The Federal Courtconvicted Japanese shipping company Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) of criminal cartel conduct and ordered it to pay a fine of $25 million.

National Australia Bank's wealth management business announced the resolution of its compensation program due to issues with its Navigator Wrap platform, with A$25 million in compensation to be paid to approximately 62,000 customers. The issues related to tax estimation and income estimation errors on its the platform.

Norwegian-based global shipping company Wallenius Wilhelmsen Ocean AS was convicted of criminal cartel conduct and ordered by the Federal Court to pay a fine of $24 million, in a case prosecuted by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.
Justice Middleton in the Federal Court, Melbourne penalized Telstra $18.55 million for denying competitors access to infrastructure in contravention of its carrier licence.

The Full Court of the Federal Court upheld an ACCC appeal, and dismissed a cross appeal by Cement Australia, against the penalties imposed on Cement Australia Pty Ltd and its related companies for making and giving effect to anti-competitive agreements. The trial judge had imposed penalties of $17.1 million against the Cement Australia companies. The Full Court ordered these companies to pay increased penalties totalling $20.6 million for breaching the anti-competitive provisions of the Act.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The Federal Court ordered Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited (ANZ) pay a A$25 million penalty for failing to provide certain benefits it had agreed to give customers with offset transaction accounts or under a Breakfree package.

Telstra paid a A$3,010,320 penalty and refunded over A$17.7 million to thousands of customers after charging them for inactive internet services over an 11-year period. A further A$3.4 million was to be refunded by the end of the year.

AGL Retail Energy Limited and three other subsidiaries of AGL Energy Limited were ordered by the Federal Court to pay penalties totaling A$25 million for failing to comply with their overcharging obligations related to Centrepay payments, in proceedings brought by the Australian Energy Regulator (AER).
Westpac Banking Corporation refunded approximately A$20 million to around 820,000 customers for not clearly disclosing the types of credit card transactions that attract foreign transaction fees.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia entered into a court enforceable undertaking with ASIC in relation to its bank bill trading business and participation in the setting of the Bank Bill Swap Rate, a key benchmark and reference interest rate in the Australian financial system. As part of the undertaking, CBA agreed to pay A$15 million to be applied to the benefit of the community and A$5 million towards ASIC's investigation and legal costs.

violation_type: drug or medical equipment safety violation
summary: The Federal Court of Australia ordered Medtronic Australasia Pty Ltd to pay A$22 million in penalties for unlawfully supplying 16,267 units of the Infuse Bone Graft Kit between 1 September 2015 and 31 January 2020.

Westpac allowed approximately 21,000 deregistered company accounts, holding approximately $120 million in funds, to remain open and continued to charge fees on those accounts. Westpac allowed funds to be withdrawn from these accounts that should have been remitted to ASIC or the Commonwealth. Justice Beach found that Westpac knew its systems were inadequate, did not fix those systems in a timely fashion and benefitted from its own conduct.

The Federal Court ordered ridesharing platform Uber to pay a penalty of $21 million after Uber admitted it had engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct and made false or misleading representations to consumers in its app and on its website, in proceedings brought by the ACCC. Uber admitted it breached the Australian Consumer Law by engaging in misleading conduct and making false or misleading representations in relation to cancellation messages and the price of Uber Taxi rides.

The Federal Court has made orders that Colgate-Palmolive Pty Ltd pay total penalties of $18 million for contraventions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now called the Competition and Consumer Act 2010), following admissions by Colgate in proceedings brought by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Colgate admitted to entering understandings which limited the supply, and controlled the price, of laundry detergents, and agreed with the ACCC to joint submissions on penalty being put to the court.

Suncorp agreed to refund 41,428 add-on insurance customers A$17.2 million for insurance bought through car dealerships that provided little or no value to consumers. The insurance was provided by MTA Insurance, owned by Suncorp.

The Federal Court declared that the two companies engaged in conduct liable to mislead the public in promotions for the Onavo Protect app, by failing to adequately disclose that users' data would be used for purposes.
The Federal Court ordered National Australia Bank Limited (NAB) to pay an A$18.5 million penalty for failures relating to misleading fee disclosure statements.
The Federal Court ordered RAMS Financial Group to pay a A$20 million penalty after it admitted to widespread compliance failures in relation to arranging home loans.

QBE Insurance (Australia) Ltd (QBE) agreed to refund more than 35,000 add-on insurance customers up to A$15.9 million they paid for insurance bought through car dealerships where the insurance provided little or no benefit.

The Federal Court ordered Visa Worldwide Pte Ltd to pay a pecuniary penalty of $18 million for engaging in anti-competitive conduct relating to currency conversion services, in proceedings brought by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

Telstra was ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of A$18 million for breaching the Australian Consumer Law after it moved almost 9,000 Belong customers to a lower speed plan without telling them.

The Federal Court ordered Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd to pay $11.25 million in penalties for engaging in cartel conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010).

Origin Energy Electricity Limited and other Origin related entities were ordered by the Federal Court to pay penalties totalling A$17 million for failing to comply with their obligations to protect customers experiencing hardship and payment difficulties.

Westpac distributed duplicate insurance policies to over 7,000 customers for the same property at the same time, including 3,899 customers since 30 November 2015, causing customers to pay for two (or more) insurance policies where they had no need for the additional policies. Westpac also issued insurance policies to 329 customers who had not consented to entering into an insurance policy.
The Federal Court ordered Air New Zealand to pay $15 million in penalties after legal action by the ACCC against a global air cargo cartel.
Origin Energy was ordered to pay A$17,605,000 by the Supreme Court of Victoria after admitting to breaches of Victoria's energy rules that affected 668,750 customers.

The Federal Court of Australia ordered National Australia Bank (NAB) pay a civil penalty in the amount of A$15 million for contravening section 31(1) of the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009 (National Credit Act).

The Federal Court in Sydney ordered Emirates to pay a total of $10 million in penalties for engaging in cartel conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010).

The Federal Court ordered National Australia Bank (NAB) and its subsidiary, AFSH Nominees Pty Ltd (AFSH), to pay a pecuniary penalty of A$15.5 million for failing to respond to customers facing hardship.

Telstra was ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of $15 million after admitting making false or misleading representations to consumers when promoting certain National Broadband Network internet plans.

Power tool supplier Techtronic was ordered to pay penalties totalling A$15 million after admitting it had engaged in resale price maintenance conduct in relation to Milwaukee branded products, including power tools, hand tools and accessories.

Samsung Electronics Australia Pty Ltd has been ordered by the Federal Court to pay $14 million in penalties after it admitted misleading consumers about the suitability of various Samsung Galaxy phones to be submerged in pool or sea water, in proceedings brought by the ACCC.

Optus, owned by Singtel, majority owned b Temasek, was ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of $13.5 million after admitting making false or misleading representations to consumers when promoting certain National Broadband Network internet plans.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The Federal Court ordered Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited (ANZ) to pay a A$15 million penalty after it admitted to misleading customers as to the funds available to those consumers in certain credit card accounts.

The Federal Court ordered EnergyAustralia to pay A$14 million in penalties for making false, misleading or deceptive statements to hundreds of thousands of consumers about electricity prices, and failing to provide mandatory information required by the Electricity Retail Code.
As a result of proceedings initiated by ACCC, an aribiter ordered Coles to refund over $12 million to suppliers to resolve allegations the company engaged in unconscionable conduct.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group agreed to compensate around 200,000 customers approximately A$13 million after it failed to accurately apply bonus interest to Progress Saver Accounts (PSA) for a number of years. The refund payment included an additional amount to recognize the time elapsed since the initial breach. ANZ reported this matter to ASIC under its breach reporting obligations in the Corporations Act.

Westpac sold consumer credit card and flexi-loan debt to debt purchasers with incorrect interest rates. These interest rates were higher than Westpac was contractually allowed to charge on at least part of the debts, resulting in more than 16,000 customers, who were likely to be in financial distress, being overcharged interest.
Westpac provided around A$11.3 million in remediation to around 3,400 credit card customers after ASIC raised concerns about its credit card limit increase practices.

company_name: The Good Guys Discount Warehouses (Australia) Pty Ltd
summary: The Federal Court ordered The Good Guys Discount Warehouses (Australia) Pty Ltd to pay A$13.5 million in penalties for misleading conduct in relation to several of its store credit and StoreCash promotions and for failing to provide store credit to more than 20,000 eligible consumers.

The Federal Court ordered Vanguard Investments Australia to pay a A$12.9 million penalty for making misleading claims about environmental, social and governance (ESG) exclusionary screens (greenwashing).

EnergyAustralia was ordered by the Federal Court to pay penalties totalling A$12 million for failing to comply with life support obligations for its customers who rely on life-saving health equipment.

The Federal Court has ordered Mercedes-Benz Australia/Pacific Pty Ltd to pay penalties of $12.5 million for failing to use attention-capturing, high-impact language when communicating with consumers about the compulsory recall of potentially deadly Takata airbags.
Allianz Australia Insurance was sentenced for six counts of disseminating information about its travel insurance coverage that was false or misleading.

Westpac agreed to provide 13,000 owner-occupiers who had interest-only home loans with an interest refund, an interest rate discount, or both. The refunds amounted to A$11 million for 9,400 of those customers.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission confirmed that ANZ would pay an additional A$10.5 million in compensation for 160,000 superannuation customers who were affected by breaches within the OnePath group between 2013 and 2016.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The ANZ bank agreed to refund A$10.2 million to 52,135 business credit card accounts, after it failed to properly disclose fees and interest charges for the product.

The Federal Court in Sydney ordered Thai Airways International Public Company to pay $7.5 million in penalties for engaging in cartel conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010).
The Commonwealth Bank agreed to refund over 65,000 customers approximately A$10 million, after selling them unsuitable consumer credit insurance (CCI).

The Federal Court ordered Mercer Financial Advice (Australia) Pty Ltd to pay a A$12 million penalty after being found to have failed in its fee disclosure obligations and charging fees to customers it was not entitled to charge.

AusNet agreed to contribute A$12 million to an Energy Resilience Community Fund as part of an enforeable undertaking to resolve allegations that it failed to provide adequate power outage information and customer communication channels to its customers after the February 2024 Victoria storms.

company_name: Ford Motor Company of Australia Limited
summary: The Federal Court declared, by consent, that Ford Motor Company of Australia Limited engaged in unconscionable conduct in the way it dealt with complaints about PowerShift transmission cars, and ordered Ford to pay $10 million in penalties.

The Federal Court ordered Telstra to pay penalties of $10 million for making false or misleading representations to customers in relation to its third-party billing service known as Premium Direct Billing, following action by the ACCC.

company_name: Westpac Securities Administration Limited and BT Funds Management Limited
summary: The Federal Court ordered Westpac Bank subsidiaries Westpac Securities Administration Limited and BT Funds Management Limited to pay a combined penalty of A$10.5 million for failing to act in their clients' best interests.

The Federal Court ordered Mazda Australia to pay A$11.5 million in penalties for engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct and making false or misleading representations to nine consumers about their consumer guarantee rights.

In a landmark greenwashing case, the Federal Court ordered Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited to pay a A$11.3 million penalty after it admitted it made misleading statements about the sustainable nature and characteristics of some of its superannuation investment options.
Subsidiaries of Singtel Optus Pty Limited received infringement notices for breaches of emergency call rules following an investigation by the Australian Communications and Media Authority.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The Federal Court of Australia ordered that Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited (ANZ) pay A$10 million in penalties after finding that ANZ engaged in unconscionable conduct and breached its obligations as a financial services licensee.

company_name: Allianz Australia Insurance Limited and AWP Australia Pty Ltd
summary: ASIC secured A$10 million in remediation from Allianz Australia Insurance Limited and AWP Australia Pty Ltd trading as Allianz Global Assistance for travel insurance potentially mis-sold to around 31,500 consumers through Allianz's own website and those of its distribution partners, including Expedia.

Westpac Banking Corporation agreed to refund approximately A$9.2 million to 161,414 customers after it failed to waive fees on Westpac and St. George branded savings and transaction accounts over six years.

The Fair Work Ombudsman has secured a record A$10.34 million in penalties against the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) and its subsidiary CommSec in response to the companies underpaying employees more than A$16 million.

The Federal Court ordered Apple Inc. to pay $9 million in penalties for making false or misleading representations to customers with faulty iPhones and iPads about their rights under the Australian Consumer Law.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: The Court found that between March 2017 and March 2018, ANZ contravened consumer credit protection laws by accepting information and documents in support of 50 home loan applications from unlicenced third parties who were not licensed to engage in credit activity. The Court also found that between November 2015 to March 2018, ANZ did not have adequate processes in place in its Introducer Program to ensure compliance and failed to take reasonable steps to ensure ANZ's representatives complied with consumer credit protection laws.

The Federal Court ordered Woolworths Limited to pay penalties totalling $9 million for contraventions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (now called the Competition and Consumer Act 2010) (the Act), following admissions made by Woolworths in proceedings brought by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
The Federal Court ordered Dell Australia to pay A$10 million for making false and misleading representations on its website about discount prices for add-on computer monitors.

The Federal Court declared that Westpac Banking Corporation engaged in unconscionable conduct in October 2016 when executing a A$12 billion interest rate swap transaction, the largest of its kind in Australian financial market history. Westpac was ordered to pay the maximum penalty of A$1.8 million in relation to the conduct, together with A$8 million for ASIC's litigation and investigation costs. Westpac's unconscionable conduct was said to have arisen when it engaged in pre-hedging ahead of an interest rate swap transaction with a Consortium comprising AustralianSuper and IFM entities. The interest rate swap related to managing interest rate risk associated with the Consortium's purchase from the NSW Government of a majority stake in electricity provider, Ausgrid.

The Federal Court ordered Macquarie Bank to pay a penalty of A$10 million for failing to have effective controls to prevent and detect unauthorised fee transactions conducted by third parties, such as financial advisers, on customer cash management accounts using Macquarie's bulk transacting facility.

The Federal Court of Australia ordered Westpac Banking Corporation to pay a penalty of A$9.15 million in respect of 22 contraventions of section 961K of the Corporations Act (the Act), and to pay ASIC's costs of the proceeding.

Oz Minerals Ltd self-reported to the AFP that employees of Oxiana (Cambodia) Limited, a foreign subsidiary of Oxiana Limited that later became a part of the Oz Minerals group, may have bribed foreign officials to obtain mining rights in Cambodia between November 2006 and October 2009. The AFP and the company agreed, pursuant to a settlement entered into on 28 April 2023, that benefits which may have been derived from the conduct that led to the acquisition of the mining rights, owned by the controlled subsidiary which has since been sold, should be confiscated. In addition to the forfeiture, worth an estimated A$5.71 million, the company agreed to pay a penalty of A$3.65 million.

The Federal Court in Sydney penalized Malaysia Airlines Cargo Sdn Bhd $6 million for price fixing as part of an air cargo cartel following action by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

The Federal Court ordered online travel agency Webjet to pay A$9 million in penalties for making false or misleading statements about the price of flights and booking confirmations, after a case run by the ACCC.

The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered a $5.5 million penalty against Japan Airlines International Co Ltd (JAL) for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in connection with air cargo.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia agreed to refund around 8,400 customers approximately A$7.6 million after it failed to apply fee waivers and ongoing benefits to AgriAdvantage Plus package holders over a number of years. The CBA reported this matter to ASIC under its breach reporting obligations in the Corporations Act.
The Federal Court in Sydney penalized Korean Air Lines Co Ltd $5.5 million for price fixing as part of an air cargo cartel.
Allianz Australia Insurance Limited agreed to refund over A$8 million in consumer credit insurance (CCI) premiums and fees including interest to more than 15,000 consumers.

The Federal Court ordered American Express Australia to pay A$8 million in penalties for breaching the design and distribution obligations (DDO) in relation to two co-branded credit cards which were primarily distributed to customers in David Jones stores.

The Federal Court of Australia ordered the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to pay a A$7 million penalty after the Court had previously declared that CBA made false or misleading representations and engaged in misleading and deceptive conduct.

The Federal Court ordered Clorox Australia Pty Ltd to pay a total penalty of A$8.25 million for making false or misleading representations to consumers that certain GLAD kitchen and garbage bags were partly made of recycled ocean plastic, following court action by the ACCC.
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia has paid a AU$7.5 million penalty after it sent more than 170 million emails that did not comply with Australia's spam laws.

Charged ongoing contribution fees for financial advice to retail customers without disclosing, or properly disclosing those fees. It is estimated that over eight years, at least 25,000 customer accounts were charged at least A$10.6 million in fees that were not disclosed, or properly disclosed.
The Full Court ordered Reckitt Benckiser to pay a revised penalty of $6 million (up from $1.7 million) for making misleading representations about its Nurofen Specific Pain products.

Justice Mansfield ordered Baxter Healthcare Pty Ltd to pay a penalty of A$4.9 million for contraventions of sections 46 and 47 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. This followed a previous decision in 2008 by the Full Federal Court declaring that Baxter had breached the misuse of market power and the exclusive dealing provisions of the Act when it entered long term contracts with State health purchasing authorities.

ING Bank (Australia) Limited, the promoter and investment manager of the ING Direct Superannuation Fund (Living Super), agreed to compensate around 24,500 members approximately A$5.38 million following ASIC concerns that statements made in its promotional material about the fees paid in connection with its Living Super product were potentially misleading.

The Federal Court imposed penalties totalling A$6 million on Honda Australia Pty Ltd, accepting Honda engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct, and made false or misleading representations to customers of former authorised Honda Australia dealerships Brighton Automotive Holdings Pty Ltd (Astoria), Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (Tynan) and Buick Holdings Pty Ltd (Burswood) by falsely stating that he dealerships would close or had closed and would no longer service Honda vehicles.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: ASICannounced a package of regulatory actions against Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) for loans approved through its former car finance business Esanda, including around $5 million in remediation.

company_name: Bupa Aged Care Australia Pty Ltd
summary: The Federal Court ordered that Bupa Aged Care Australia Pty Ltd pay $6 million in penalties for making misleading representations and wrongly accepting payments for extra services not provided or only provided in part to residents at 20 aged care homes.

Citigroup Pty Limited refunded approximately A$5 million to around 230,000 customers, for failing to properly disclose that credit card international transaction fees apply to Australian dollar transactions where the merchant uses an entity based overseas to process its transactions.

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group agreed to refund around 25,000 customers approximately A$5 million after it failed to properly apply some fee reductions and fee waivers for customers who held an ANZ Access Basic account and who also held an ANZ consumer credit card or ANZ Everyday Visa Debit Card since 2007.
Origin Energy paid penalties totalling A$5 million after allegedly charging prohibited exit fees to more than 20,000 gas and electricity small business customers.

Bankwest, a division of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, refunded approximately 10,800 customers more than A$4.9 million after it failed to link offset accounts to home loan accounts for some customers who had open accounts between 2007 and June 2016, resulting in customers being overcharged interest.

Coles Group Limited agreed to pay Norco Co-operative Limited around $5.25 million for distribution to its dairy farmer members. The payments followed an ACCC investigation into whether Coles fully passed on to Norco a 10 cents per litre price rise it charged consumers for Coles branded fresh milk, as it claimed it would do in Coles' marketing materials.

The Federal Court of Australia ordered CBA to pay a A$5 million penalty after the Court found that CBA had breached the ASIC Act and Corporations Act for failures of their AgriAdvantage Plus Package (AA+ Package). The Court also ordered CBA to publish a Corrective Notice in the form determined by the Court.

Following an ASIC investigation, the Markets Disciplinary Panel (MDP) fined Macquarie Bank Limited A$4.995 million for failing to prevent suspicious orders being placed on the electricity futures market.
Four Jemena subsidiaries were ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of A$5.5 million for breaches of the National Gas Rules related to the Day Ahead Auction (DAA).

company_name: Volkswagen Financial Services Australia Pty Limited
summary: ASIC settled its claim against Volkswagen Financial Services Australia Pty Limited (VWFSA), discontinuing its Federal Court proceeding and accepting a Court Enforceable Undertaking (CEU) from the car financier. The CEU will see VWFSA implement a consumer remediation program which will provide an estimated $4.7 million in redress to approximately 1,800 consumers.
The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered four foreign-based suppliers of marine hose to pay penalties exceeding $8.24 million for engaging in cartel conduct.
